oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery Interviews Ronnie McDowell - Parts 1, 2 and 3
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Ronnie McDowell (performer) for the Ralph Emery Show. Tape labeled parts 1, 2 and 3. Recording is from June 24, 1982.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Ronnie McDowell
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Ronnie McDowell radio spot for the Ralph Emery Show -- (00:13) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery introduction voiceover] -- (00:37) Emery and McDowell greet each other, and Emery asks about his memory of the first time he was on the Ralph Emery Show -- (02:40) Emery inquires about McDowell's popularity among the older population -- (04:04)Emery jokes about the first time he saw "I Just Cut Myself" -- (04:52) Emery invites McDowell to discuss his restaurant the Good Ole Days -- (07:04) McDowell introduces "Whatever" by the Statler Brothers -- (07:34) Emery inquires about McDowell's relationship with Jamie O'Hara -- (09:09) Emery asks McDowell about how tired he is; additionally, McDowell reflects on his Elvis Presley image -- (12:37) Emery reflects on how he believes McDowell is similar to Tanya Tucker -- (13:08) McDowell introduces "Cheater's Prayer" while discussing the Kendalls' home town -- (14:15) Emery and McDowell discuss Bobby Bare's laid-back personality -- (14:45) Emery and McDowell reflect on the film career of Ferlin Husky -- (15:32) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Ronnie McDowell outro voiceover] -- (16:47) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Ronnie McDowell introduction voiceover] -- (17:04) Darlene Austin, McDowell, and Emery discuss what McDowell knows -- (18:40) Emery introduces Austin and asks McDowell to interview him -- (20:28) Emery questions Austin about where she grew up and what she was doing in Nashville -- (23:09) Emery inquires about David Havner and has Austin introduce "Love Busted" by Billy 'Crash' Craddock -- (24:23) Emery and McDowell joke about McDowell's nickname -- (25:15) Emery inquires about Austin and McDowell's upcoming joint ventures -- (28:00) Emery reflects on the songs that directly relate to the artists wife; additionally, McDowell enjoys being an opening act -- (30:08) Austin discusses her enjoyment from performing Alabama's "Why Baby Why" -- (30:47) Emery inquires about Austin's discipline with her band -- (32:18) Emery asks Austin to introduce McDowell -- (32:56) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Emery, Austin and McDowell outro voiceover] -- (34:18) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Ronnie McDowell introduction voiceover] -- (34:35) McDowell introduces Keren Cain's "I'll be Your Man of the House" -- (34:56) Emery asks McDowell about why he chose to record Conway Twitty's "It's Only Make Believe" -- (38:16) Emery recalls a show he did with Ann Murray while introducing a Murray segment -- (38:48) Emery plays a segment with Murray where both discuss "Please Don't Sell Nova Scotia" -- (40:22) Emery introduces Waylon Jennings' "Honky Tonk Blues" -- (41:02) McDowell discusses how Gene Watson's appearance has changed over time while introducing "This Dreams on Me" -- (41:38) "I Just Cut Myself" is introduced and Emery inquires about what McDowell believes to be a hit -- (43:22) Emery recalls a time at a hotel where a television show reminded him of "I Just Cut Myself" -- (43:58) McDowell praises Sylvia while introducing "Nobody" -- (44:28) Emery and McDowell discuss how McDowell discovered his great-grandfather was one of three McDowells to cross into the new world -- (47:24) Emery praises McDowell's "Only the Lonely" which happened to be the first record McDowell recorded -- (48:25) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Emery and McDowell outro voiceover]
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; McDowell, Ronnie;
